page.title: 14Water - Chew Valley Lake
page.content: One of six largest reservoirs in the country, the Chew Valley Lake has a capacity of about 5m gallons. A dam was constructed across the valley of the River Chew at Chew Stoke and the river diverted. The Lake extends for well over 2 miles along the valley. In order to preserve everthing possible of historic interest, the whole area was very carefully photographed; records of old farmhouses have been preserved and Stratford Mill was taken down and re-erected in the grounds of Blaise Castle and is still in working order with its original machinery. Around the Reservoir and on the Denny Island many types of trees have been planted so the the Lakes blend with the surroundings and anyone coming to the area in 1985 would assume that they have always been here. People from far afield come for recreation.
